content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: interesting task, easily solvable for a clash of code

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: clear task, not too easy nor too difficult.

Nice one, managed to solve it, however both your solution and mine, cannot validate correctly a custom scenario such as:
n=2
s=2
c="101 100"

your solution outputs: 0 1

Which means a bushel does not get allocated.

So I suggest to specify clearly in the Statement goal how to evenly distribute the bushels instead of "fill them as evenly as possible" and/or to correct your solution accordingly.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The contribution is a fun puzzle that you have to think about, but not for too long

If you aren't going to make major changes to the inputs any more, please at least state that when all the silos are empty, a space character is given as [[C]].

Otherwise the statement specification is incomplete.

Thank you.

All Silos Empty (Test/Validator)
* As per the statement, empty silos are not listed in [[C]]. However, in this pair of test and validator, [[C]] is given as 0. That is contradictory.

Constraints section
* Suggest to mention that the cases are designed such that there is only one possible solution.

Note: I am thinking about cases like
101
2
100 70
where the answer can be 35 66 or 36 65, so there can be more than one possible solution.

Thanks.

5DN1L, Great feedback.  Thank you. With regards to your first comment, I couldn't find how to have an empty string in the input (or for that matter, nothing for the output).  Could you point me in the right direction?  Thanks again!
Removed the All empty silo scenario and test case and changed the constraint.  I still haven't ben able to find the correct method for handling an empty input or empty output.

There are possible scenarios that either leave leftover grain or require instructions on where to put the remainder. In order to keep the problem and its statement more simple, those scenarios are excluded from the test cases.  I have added additional wording to constraints to make that clear.  Thank you for raising the point.
I don't know a way either. Probably it's easier to add "unless all silos are empty, in which case a single {{0}} is listed in [[C]]".

Changes have been made to address the comments above.  An empty line with just a single space on it appears to work for an empty string input.  I still don't know how to allow for a valid empty output - whether it is nothing or an empty string.

First, would you please move "There is only one correct answer for the inputs given." from Output section to Constraints section?

Back to the empty silos issue:

I've just experimented a little. Having all the numbers in the same line doesn't work. But it seems that having them in different lines works, so e.g. the Some Empty Silos test becomes:
1200
6 3
300
400
200
and the All Silos Empty test becomes:
1200
10 0<no newline here>
<nothing below here>

The corresponding stub generator is like this:
read N:int
read Total_Silos:int Total_NonEmptySilos:int
loop Total_NonEmptySilos read C:int
write answer

You'll have to specify the number of non-empty silos to make this work though. But you don't have to add spaces or zeros for [[C]] any more, and it makes parsing nicer overall, because integers are passed to the player, instead of a string being passed.
